text.p: Following are the top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Fireballs shot 80 metres into the air as 200-litre drums of chemicals exploded in a fire in a Tuas factory.

- As the hustings for Indonesia's sixth parliamentary elections come to what many hope will be a peaceful halt, 22,000 police and troops poured into the capital and surrounding satellite towns in an all-out effort to pre-empt the sporadic violence that has marred the 27-day campaigning.
- A Filipino maid has been arrested for the suspected murder of her sister-in-law, also a maid.
- Potential executive condominium buyers may have to pay between S$440 and $480 per square foot for the first two tender sites, which received an overwhelming response.
- Singapore which emerged second in terms of competitiveness, is now an industrialised nation, says a top Swiss business school in its 1997 world competitiveness ranking.

- Indonesian conglomerate P.T. Sinar Mas Tunggal revealed details of its property, food processing and agriculture assets which will be injected into Asia Food & Properties, its vehicle for the takeover of troubled Amcol Holdings.
- The first tender for two sites for executive condominiums drew a barrage of bids, with the top bids pointing to as much as 10 percent increase in selling prices.

- Alarmed by the frenzied demand for funds to subscribe for new share offers of so-called red chips or mainland-backed Hongkong companies, stock market regulators have imposed a "fair and orderly" method of share allocation for future offers.

- One-third of the 75,000 households queuing to buy another brand new Housing Board flat will be hit by the latest 10-year time bar imposed by the government, according to the Ministry of National Development.
- A public outcry over rising crime in Taiwan has forced President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Lien Chan to give up golf.
- Keppel Land is beefing up its march into the Singapore and regional property scene with giant Dutch group Rodamco as partner.
- The Hai Sun Hup Group, a shipping firm which has bought several hotels in Australia, may float its Australian assets in a few months, says group chairman C K Ow.
- Amcol Holdings will become the fourth division of Asia Food & Properties, the Singapore $3.2 billion Singapore-based subsidiary of Indonesia's Sinar Mas group.
- United Overseas Land has secured official approval to develop a plot of land behind the Landmark Parkroyal Hotel in Sydney, Australia, into a 110-unit apartment.
